qas.question: What is the earliest example of Greek architecture in France?

answers.text: Charles de Wailly's crypt in the church of St Leu-St Gilles (1773–80

qas.question: How concerned was France with Greek architecture?

answers.text: Greek architecture was of very little importance to the French

qas.question: Who's influence brought about Greek revival in France?
In which wave of neoclassical was the greek revival in France?
Who consider first-hand evidence of Greek architecture very important?
What sought to discern the practices of the Greeks?
What started with the crypt of Claude Nicholas Ludoux?

context: What little there was, started with <a0_0>Charles de Wailly's crypt in the church of St Leu-St Gilles (1773–80<a0_0/>), and Claude Nicolas Ledoux's Barriere des Bonshommes (1785–89). First-hand evidence of <a1_0>Greek architecture was of very little importance to <b4_0>the French<a1_0/>,<b4_0/> due to the influence of <b5_0>Marc-Antoine Laugier's doctrines<b5_0/> that sought to discern the principles of the Greeks instead of their mere practices. It would take until <a2_0>Laboustre<a2_0/>'s Neo-Grec of the <a3_0>second Empire<a3_0/> for the <b6_0><b7_0>Greek<b6_0/> revival<b7_0/> to flower briefly in France.
